abstract.p: Letter from Anne LaGrange Loving notes that some organs of elderly can be used for variety of donor procedures after they die

block.p: Re ''Turning the Grief-Stricken Toward Organ Donation'' (news article, Jan. 16): It is important to note that young healthy people who die from accidents are not the only candidates for organ donation.

Re ''Turning the Grief-Stricken Toward Organ Donation'' (news article, Jan. 16): It is important to note that young healthy people who die from accidents are not the only candidates for organ donation.

When my 85-year-old mother passed away after a miserable decline involving multiple medical conditions, I was shocked that within minutes of her death, I was approached about offering her body for organ donation.
After I was informed that the whites of her eyes, parts of her bones and parts of her skin could be used for a variety of donor procedures, I immediately consented.
Those who would like to be organ donors but fear they are too old should make their wishes known to their families, and keep their organ-donor cards with them.
Anne LaGrange Loving Ridgewood, N.J., Jan. 16, 2007
